name: Ponczki
author: Karen Gibson
summary: This is the 'traditional' ponczki made by most Polish Grandmothers, like mine.  These take time and patience, but the product is worth it. Preferred, traditional frying method is with lard but oil will work fine.  I usually mix equal portions.  Grandma used a large paper bag, and dropped them in immediately after removing from the fryer.  The bag absorbs a lot of the oil.  Then, she transferred them to another clean bag, added her choice of coating, and shook the bag.
directions: In a large bowl, crumble yeast in lukewarm milk
Stir well, and allow to rest 1 hour in a warm place
Soften chopped raisins in warm water for 30 minutes
Beat egg, egg yolks, sugar, vanilla, melted butter, salt, and orange zest
Stir in raisins; add egg mixture and mix until combined
Add 4 cups flour and mix well, forming smooth ball
Dough will be somewhat soft, but not batter-like
Cover dough, and allow to rise until fully doubled, about 1 1/2 hours
Punch down, let rise until double again, about 45 minutes to an hour
On a lightly floured surface, divide dough into quarters
Working with one quarter at a time, divide it into 12 pieces; keep other pieces of dough covered while you work
Roll the pieces into 1/2 inch balls; set aside to rise until doubled in bulk, about 30 minutes
Heat oil in a deep-fryer or large saucepan to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C)
Drop 2 or 3 at a time into hot fat, turn when deep golden brown
If removed too soon, dough will be under-done inside
When doughnuts are browned, drain briefly on paper towels and dust with confectioners' sugar or cinnamon sugar (see Cook's Note)
